questions.text: A 65-year-old female presents with acute onset pain, redness, and blurring of vision in the right eye. On examination, her intraocular pressure (IOP) is 48 mmHg, and there is a shallow anterior chamber with a hazy cornea. Slit-lamp examination reveals an intumescent, swollen lens with the iris pushed forward. Gonioscopy shows a closed angle. What is the most likely underlying mechanism for her glaucoma?

options.label: A
options.text: Obstruction of the trabecular meshwork by inflammatory cells

options.label: B
options.text: Forward displacement of the lens due to an abnormal zonular attachment

options.label: C
options.text: Disruption of aqueous humor flow due to posterior synechiae

options.label: D
options.text: Pupillary block caused by the swollen lens

questions.correct_answer: D. Pupillary block caused by the swollen lens

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is not typically associated with secondary congenital glaucoma?
questions.explanation:
Secondary Developmental/ Congenital Glaucoma

Associated Ocular Anomalies

Associated Systemic Anomalies

Glaucoma Associated with Iridodysgenesis:

  • Aniridia (50% of cases) (Option A ruled out)
  • Familial Iris Hypoplasia
  • Congenital Ectropion Uvea
  • Congenital Microcornea
  • Congenital Nanophthalmos

Chromosomal Disorders:

  • Trisomy 13 (Patau Syndrome)
  • Trisomy 18 (Edward’s Syndrome)
  • Trisomy 21 (Down Syndrome)
  • Turner Syndrome (Option C ruled out)

Ectopia Lentis Syndromes:

  • Marfan Syndrome (Option B ruled out)
  • Weill-Marchesani Syndrome
  • Homocystinuria

Glaucoma Associated with Iridocorneal Dysgenesis:

  • Posterior Embryotoxon: Prominent Schwalbe's ring.
  • Axenfeld-Rieger Syndrome:
    • Axenfeld Anomaly: Posterior embryotoxon with peripheral iris tissue strands.
    • Rieger Anomaly: Posterior embryotoxon, iris hypoplasia, ectropion ,iris defects.
    • Rieger Syndrome: Rieger anomalies with dental, facial, and other systemic anomalies.
  • Peter's Anomaly: Central corneal opacity with or without iris or lens adhesions.
  • Combined Rieger’s Syndrome and Peter’s Anomaly: Features of both conditions.

Phakomatosis :

  • Sturge-Weber Syndrome (50% of cases)
  • Von Recklinghausen’s Neurofibromatosis (25% of cases)

Metabolic Syndromes:

  • Lowe’s Syndrome: Oculocerebrorenal syndrome.
  • Hurler’s Syndrome: Mucopolysaccharidosis.
  • Zellweger Syndrome: Hepato-cerebral renal syndrome.

questions.text: A 6-month-old infant with congenital glaucoma has corneal enlargement, clouding, and Haab’s striae and the angle is difficult to visualize due to corneal clouding. Which surgical procedure is most appropriate for this infant?

A 1-month-old child presents with persistent eye watering and light sensitivity. Examination shows enlarged corneas with Haab’s striae, cloudiness, a deep anterior chamber, and thin, blue sclera. The child has had ocular enlargement since birth. The ophthalmologist suspects congenital glaucoma. Which type of glaucoma best fits this presentation?
questions.explanation:
Primary Congenital Glaucoma

Types

1. Newborn glaucoma/ True congenital glaucoma: Elevated intraocular pressure is present during intrauterine life, resulting in ocular enlargement at birth. (40% cases) (Option C)

Typically presents within the first month of life.

Often associated with developmental anomalies of the anterior segment, such as primary congenital glaucoma, which can result from genetic mutations or other congenital conditions.

 

2. Infantile: ≤ 3 yrs of age- (Option B ruled out) Infantile glaucoma is labelled when the disease manifests prior to the child's third birthday

Affects infants older than 1 month and children up to 3 years.

Can also result from genetic factors or be secondary to other conditions like Sturge-Weber syndrome or other syndromic associations.

3. Juvenile: > 3 yrs of age (Option A ruled out) who develop pressure rise after 3 years but before adulthood. Also known as Juvenile primary open angle glaucoma(POAG) usually occurs between 10 to 35 years of age.

Buphthalmos, meaning "bull-like eyes," is a condition characterized by the enlargement of the eyeball. It typically manifests before the age of 3 years and results from the accumulation and retention of aqueous humor.

Pathogenesis
  • Trabeculodysgenesis: Maldevelopment of the trabeculum and iridotrabecular junction from neural crest cells impairs aqueous outflow, causing elevated IOP.
  • Angle Recess Absence: The angle recess is absent, with the iris inserting either flatly or concavely into the trabeculum.
  • Iris Insertion Types:
    • Flat Insertion: Reveals the ciliary body and scleral spur.
    • Concave Insertion: Obscures the scleral spur and ciliary body.

Clinical Features

Classic Triad: Lacrimation, photophobia, and blepharospasm; often accompanied by eye rubbing.

Corneal Signs:

  • Oedema: Early sign, may progress to permanent opacity.
  • Enlargement: Corneal diameter >13 mm confirms enlargement; >16 mm indicates poor prognosis.

Haab’s Striae: Tears in Descemet's membrane, visible as opaque lines.

 

Additional Features:

  • Thin Sclera: Appears blue due to underlying uveal tissue.
  • Deep Anterior Chamber: Indicates elevated IOP.
  • Iris Changes: Iridodonesis and atrophic patches in late stages.
  • Lens Changes: Becomes flat and may subluxate.
  • Optic Disc Changes: Variable cupping and atrophy.
  • Raised IOP: Elevated but not acute.
  • Axial Myopia: Due to increased axial length.

questions.text: A 50-year-old glaucoma patient is prescribed a prostaglandin analog as first-line therapy. Which of the following is the most likely mechanism of action and a common side effect of this medication?

options.label: A
options.text: Reduces aqueous humor production; Lid retraction

options.label: D
options.text: Decreases aqueous humor secretion; Allergic blepharoconjunctivitis

questions.correct_answer: C. Increases uveoscleral outflow; Iris pigmentation

questions.text: All of the following are penetrating glaucoma surgeries except:
Which of the following laser procedures are used for Open angle glaucoma (OAG) and angle closure glaucoma (ACG) respectively?

options.label: A
options.text: Argon laser iridotomy for open-angle glaucoma and selective laser trabeculoplasty (SLT) for angle closure glaucoma

options.label: B
options.text: Selective laser trabeculoplasty for open-angle glaucoma and laser iridotomy for angle closure glaucoma

options.label: C
options.text: Laser iridoplasty for open-angle glaucoma and argon laser iridotomy for angle closure glaucoma

options.label: D
options.text: Laser iridotomy for open-angle glaucoma and laser iridoplasty for angle closure glaucoma

questions.correct_answer: B. Selective laser trabeculoplasty for open-angle glaucoma and laser iridotomy for angle closure glaucoma

questions.text: A 65-year-old male presents to the ophthalmology clinic for a routine eye examination. During the examination, his intraocular pressure (IOP) is measured at 28 mmHg in both eyes. The ophthalmologist diagnoses him with primary open-angle glaucoma. Which of the following medications is primarily designed to lower intraocular pressure by reducing the production of aqueous humor?
Which ICE syndrome is characterized by the presence of pigmented nodular lesions on the iris?
Which of the following statements is false about traumatic glaucoma?

options.label: A
options.text: Traumatic glaucoma can develop from both perforating and blunt injuries.

options.label: B
options.text: Angle recession glaucoma typically presents with elevated IOP shortly after the trauma.

options.label: C
options.text: Lens-induced glaucoma can occur due to a ruptured, swollen, or dislocated lens following trauma.

options.label: D
options.text: Peripheral anterior synechiae from corneal injury can lead to angle-closure glaucoma.

questions.correct_answer: B. Angle recession glaucoma typically presents with elevated IOP shortly after the trauma.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presents with unilateral eye discomfort, blurred vision, and seeing halos around lights. On examination, his intraocular pressure (IOP) is measured at 48 mm Hg. The anterior segment shows a few small, flat, nonpigmented keratic precipitates located inferiorly, mild redness, and an aqueous flare. The pupil is dilated, but there are no signs of a posterior synechiae. The patient reports recurrent episodes that resolve within days to weeks. Given these findings, what is the most likely diagnosis?

options.label: A
options.text: Secondary Angle-Closure Glaucoma with Pupillary Block

options.label: B
options.text: Secondary Angle-Closure Glaucoma without Pupillary Block

questions.text: A 70-year-old patient with a history of glaucoma undergoes a trabeculectomy to control intraocular pressure. Postoperatively, the patient presents with severe eye pain, blurred vision, a significantly elevated intraocular pressure (IOP), and a shallow anterior chamber. Seidel's test is negative. What is the most appropriate initial treatment for this condition?
questions.correct_answer: C. Atropine drops and oral acetazolamide

questions.text: A 58-y/o diabetic patient presents with decreased vision, eye pain, and redness in the right eye. Examination reveals iris neovascularization, elevated intraocular pressure, and proliferative diabetic retinopathy. What is the most appropriate management strategy?

options.label: A
options.text: Topical beta-blockers and oral carbonic anhydrase inhibitors

questions.text: A 55-year-old Asian woman presents with acute eye pain and blurred vision. Her ophthalmologist suspects primary angle closure glaucoma (PACG). Which of the following statements about the etiopathogenesis of PACG is incorrect?

options.label: A
options.text: Pupillary block is the most common mechanism in PACG

options.label: B
options.text: Phacomorphic mechanism involves an abnormally large lens pushing the iris forward

options.label: C
options.text: Plateau iris configuration is more common in younger patients with PACG

options.label: D
options.text: Caucasians have a higher prevalence of PACG compared to other ethnicities

questions.correct_answer: D. Caucasians have a higher prevalence of PACG compared to other ethnicities
questions.explanation:
Risk Factors

Mechanisms

Demographic factors:

  • Age: 6th and 7th decades of life
  • Gender: Female to male ratio 1:3
  • Ethnicity: More common in Asians

1. Pupillary block (70% of cases): (Option A ruled out)

  • Most common mechanism (70% of cases)
  • Increased contact between iris and lens
  • Precipitating factors:
    • Physiological mydriasis (e.g., dim illumination, emotional stress)
    • Pharmacological mydriasis (e.g., tropicamide, cyclopentolate)
  • Results in relative pupil block

Anatomical factors:

  • Hypermetropic eyes
  • Shallow anterior chamber
  • Short axial length
  • Thick, anteriorly positioned lens
  • Small corneal diameter
  • Plateau iris configuration

2. Plateau iris configuration:

  • Anteriorly positioned ciliary processes
  • More common in younger patients (Option C ruled out)
  • Can persist after iridotomy
  • Associated with angle closure glaucoma without pupillary block

Other factors:

  • Family history
  • Diabetes mellitus
  • Certain medications (e.g., topiramate)

3. Phacomorphic mechanism: (Option B ruled out)

  • Swollen lens contributes to angle closure
  • Can cause pupillary block or push peripheral iris forward
  • Can occur in acute or chronic forms
  • Associated with intumescent or other lens morphological abnormalities

questions.text: A 72-year-old male presents with diminution of vision in the right eye. On slit-lamp examination, dandruff-like material is noted on the anterior lens capsule and iris. Intraocular pressure is elevated, and the patient is diagnosed with pseudoexfoliative glaucoma. Which of the following is most likely to be observed in this patient’s eye?

A 25-year-old myopic male presents with intermittent blurring of vision and mild ocular pain after exercise. On examination, IOP is 28 mmHg, Slit lamp examination reveals Krukenberg spindle on corneal endothelium, trabecular pigmentation on gonioscopy. Which of the following is the first-line treatment?

A 45-year-old male presents with unilateral eye pain, redness, and moderately elevated intraocular pressure (IOP) of 28 mmHg. On slit-lamp examination, you observe fine, pigmented deposits on the corneal endothelium in a vertical spindle pattern. The patient O/E has symmetric transillumination defects in the mid-peripheral iris. Based on these findings, which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's secondary glaucoma?

A 65-year-old male presents with a painful, blind right eye. On examination, the eye is stony hard with no light perception, 100% cupping of the optic disc, and a fixed, mid-dilated pupil. Which of the following is the correct initial management?
All of the following components of Vogt's triad are typically observed in a patient who has experienced and resolved an acute primary angle-closure glaucoma (APAC) attack except?

A 55-year-old female presents for a routine eye examination. During gonioscopy, the examination reveals an occludable anterior chamber angle bilaterally. The patient reports no visual symptoms, and intraocular pressure (IOP) measurements are within normal limits. There is no evidence of glaucomatous damage on optic nerve examination. What is the most appropriate next step in management for this patient?
What aspect of the anterior chamber does the Van Herick grading system evaluate during slit lamp examination?

options.label: B
options.text: The width of the anterior chamber angle

questions.correct_answer: B. The width of the anterior chamber angle
questions.explanation:
Width of the empty space (LACD) as compared to the corneal thickness

VAN Herick Grade

Angle status

No black space observed

0

Closed

<¼ corneal thickness

1

Extremely narrow

¼ of corneal thickness

2

Narrow

>¼ to ½ of corneal thickness

3

Open

≥ 1/2 of corneal thickness

4

Wide open

questions.text: In the Shaffer classification system for grading the anterior chamber angle, which grade indicates that the angle is fully open with visible structures such as the scleral spur and trabecular meshwork?
questions.explanation:
ACA in degrees

ACA grade

Angle status

Visible structures

0

0

Closed

No structures visible

1

Extremely narrow

Schwalbe’s line

11-19

2

Narrow

Trabecular meshwork

20-34

3

Open

35-45

Ciliary body

questions.text: Which of the following best describes the principle of gonioscopy?

options.label: B
options.text: It is a technique for visualizing the anterior chamber angle of the eye using a special lens

options.label: C
options.text: It is a technique for visualizing the posterior chamber angle of the eye using a special lens

questions.correct_answer: B. It is a technique for visualizing the anterior chamber angle of the eye using a special lens

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents with intermittent eye pain and blurred vision. Gonioscopy reveals narrow angles, and the angle remains narrow after laser peripheral iridotomy. Which of the following statements about plateau iris configuration is incorrect ?

options.label: A
options.text: It is characterized by an anteriorly positioned ciliary body

options.label: B
options.text: It is more commonly seen in older patients with primary angle closure glaucoma

options.label: C
options.text: Plateau iris configuration can persist after iridotomy

options.label: D
options.text: Ultrasound biomicroscopy (UBM) can be useful in diagnosing this condition

questions.correct_answer: B. It is more commonly seen in older patients with primary angle closure glaucoma
questions.explanation:
Anatomy
  • Plateau iris is characterized by an anteriorly positioned ciliary body, which pushes the peripheral iris forward.
  • This creates a "table-top" or plateau-like appearance of the iris.

Age of presentation
  • It is more commonly seen in younger patients with primary angle closure glaucoma.
  • This is in contrast to the pupillary block, which is more common in older individuals.

Diagnostic tools
  • Ultrasound biomicroscopy (UBM) is particularly useful in diagnosing plateau iris configuration. (Option D)

Management
  • Due to its persistence after iridotomy, patients with plateau iris may require additional treatments such as: (Option C)
    • Argon laser peripheral iridoplasty
    • Long-term use of miotic drops

questions.text: A 50-year-old patient presents with symptoms suggesting possible angle-closure glaucoma. You want to perform a comprehensive assessment of the anterior chamber angle. Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding anterior chamber angle assessment and anatomy?

options.label: A
options.text: Gonioscopy is the definitive diagnostic tool for primary angle closure.

options.label: B
options.text: Normal angle structures from anterior to posterior include: Schwalbe's line, non-pigmented trabecular meshwork, pigmented trabecular meshwork, scleral spur, and ciliary body band.

options.label: C
options.text: An angle is considered occludable if the pigmented trabecular meshwork is not visible in less than 180 degrees without indentation.

options.label: D
options.text: Indirect gonioscopes used to measure angle of AC are goldmann, posner-ritch, zeiss

questions.correct_answer: C. An angle is considered occludable if the pigmented trabecular meshwork is not visible in less than 180 degrees without indentation.
questions.explanation:
Indirect (Option D ruled out)

Direct

Provides a mirror image of the opposite angle


 

Provides a direct view of the angle

Example :

 

1. Goldmann lenses

  • Single mirror
  • Surger
  • Two mirror
  • Three mirror

2. Zeiss

3. Susman

4. Posner – Ritch

Example:

 

1. Koeppe

2. Swan – Jacob
